Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the creation of a platform technology with a rapidly deployable, motorized arm that can be used wherever rapid, precise positioning of objects is required. There are many potential medical, commercial, industrial, and consumer applications for the technology. In the industrial sector there are needs to position and hold for assembly, soldering, gluing, welding, or metrology. The device can also support needs for mechanical assistance during disassembly and re-assembly in maintenance operations. Consumer applications include holding tablets, books, or laptops and adjustable workbench arms. Medical applications include surgical retraction and surgical device or tool holding, including laparoscopic instruments. The first target application in development is an abdominal surgical retraction system that can be deployed and/or adjusted within seconds. A rapidly deployable retractor reduces operating room and anesthesia times. Further, since the retractor arm is disposable, the risk of infection is reduced, and the need for cleaning, sterilization, and maintenance is eliminated.

This I-Corps team has developed a device that consists of a motorized base with an attached flexible arm that can be locked into place and/or adjusted in seconds at the push and release of a button. Various grippers can be attached to the end of the arm to firmly and steadily grasp or support an object at any orientation. The speed and flexibility of these devices provide advantages over slower, manually operated fixtures, especially when working in and around complex geometries or fragile environments. The intellectual property consists of a unique joint surface that permits the mechanical arm to be made much longer and stronger than competing systems. A first generation system that operates as a surgical retractor was built and demonstrated before surgeons in mock scenario in a hospital operating room. It was shown to be capable of providing adequate retraction force for abdominal surgeries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF I-Corps: Surgical Retractor System award revealed the existence of a market need and commercialization strategy for an adjustable, flexible, disposable abdominal surgical retractor (a tool for holding back tissue and organs during surgery). Extensive interviews with various stakeholders clarified the needs of individuals involved with use and purchase of surgical tools. Surgeons need tools that can be quickly deployed and adjusted and that maximize their ability to see the operative site. Surgeons and surgical staff both benefit from being able to focus on the details of the surgery, rather than diverting attention to struggle with equipment. Surgical staff, hospital system administrators, and payers all benefit when new equipment provides new capabilities at lower cost (preparatory/operative/post-operative time, sterilization, maintenance) than use of incumbent equipment. Naturally, satisfying these needs benefits patients via direct and indirect improvements in patient care and overall healthcare cost reduction. From the perspective of a purchaser, improvements in patient outcomes such as infection rate are notoriously difficult to attribute to individual devices (and thus inappropriate for economic justification or proof of efficacy of a device or technique). However, several stakeholder discovery interviews suggested that both medical teams and hospital administrators will ?do whatever is best for our patients, even if it?s more expensive.?

Moving the core technology to market requires proving economic feasibility (cost of device manufacturing and use), as well as satisfying regulatory standards regarding device safety. A feasible strategy for all aspects of part fabrication, cleaning, clean assembly, sterilization, and packaging is necessary to enable a start-up to bring a product to market. Acquiring appropriate experts to ensure regulatory compliance, quality and safety is key to a timely market entry.

After completion of formal training in the I-Corps Teams program and additional customer discovery indicating a viable business was feasible, a new company was formed to commercialize the core innovation. This award also supported the professional development of the PI, entrepreneurial lead, and I-Corps Mentor in entrepreneurial concepts. Understanding how to assess the need and impact of societal problems helps ensure future research has applicability and utility to the public.
